content.text: Utrecht Centraal is one of the busiest train stations in the Netherlands. Don't be afraid to ask an NS (Dutch Railways) employee for help. They wear blue and yellow uniforms.
The OV-chipkaart is the card for all public transport. You must 'inchecken' (check in) at a gate or post before your journey and 'uitchecken' (check out) at your destination.

content.title: Get Help Urgently
content.setting: You're in a hurry at Utrecht Centraal. You see an NS employee and need to ask for help finding your train to Rotterdam.

conversation_flow.title: Get the employee's attention and say you have a question
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: (An NS employee in a blue and yellow uniform notices you looking lost.) Goedemiddag, kan ik u helpen?

conversation_flow.title: Tell them you need the train to Rotterdam

data.tip: Like the English word 'spore', but with a more rounded 'o' sound and a rolled 'r' if you can.

content.text: Dutch numbers can be tricky. For example, 21 is 'eenentwintig' (one-and-twenty). It's normal to ask someone to repeat a number.

content.title: Understand the Directions
content.setting: The employee is telling you the platform number, but it's noisy and they spoke quickly.

conversation_flow.title: You didn't catch the number. Ask them to repeat it more slowly
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: De Intercity naar Rotterdam vertrekt van spoor achttien.

content.text: 'Dank u wel' is slightly more formal and polite than 'Dank je wel'. Both are perfect for this situation with a service employee.

content.title: Confirm and Go
content.setting: You think you heard 'platform 18'. You want to confirm before you run off.

conversation_flow.title: Confirm the platform number by repeating it as a question
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Natuurlijk. Spoor... acht... tien. Dat is spoor 18.

conversation_flow.title: Thank the employee and wish them a nice day
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ja, dat klopt. Spoor 18. De trein vertrekt over 5 minuten, u moet een beetje haasten!
